reviews.text: We enjoyed a wonderful takeout dining experience this evening and will look forward to dining in once restaurants are once again open. The chef competed on masterchef and the food is most certainly evidence of why he was selected as a competitor. Incredibly well balanced flavors, creative construction, and well executed food made for a fantastic dining experience. The portions are extremely generous given the quality and intensity of flavor. Highly highly recommended!
This place is available on Chowbus as "Master Chef" making a large range of foods, from paella to katsudon. They also serve the best Una dish around campus.

I have traveled a lot for work on expense accounts and I haven't been able to find many restaurants worth going to around here, so I generally don't eat out. I was really impressed with Bowen Bistro's quality of ingredients for the price.

I know there are some not great reviews, but I think when you go, you need to take your server's recommendations. We ordered an appetizer and asked her if it was good, and she said it was ok. She was right, it was just ok. However, we ordered her two favorite dishes, the crispy skin salmon and the aged NY strip, and they were DELICIOUS. You would pay about 30% more for the same quality of ingredients elsewhere. The crispy skin salmon is one of the best things I have eaten at any restaurant ever including restaurants in Chicago, San Francisco, NYC, New Orleans, etc. The mashed potatoes are so good we ordered an extra side.

We will definitely be back. Oh my goodness, and the bourbon cake and tiramisu are incredible. I was surprised they were handmade. I can't wait to go back and try the duck, and of course, get the perfect crispy salmon again!

My partner and I went to Bowen's for lunch and had a GREAT experience. It was a creative, fun lunch menu that pokes into high-end cuisine. We started with an appetizer of the Ahi Poke, which was a really flavorful bite before digging into our main dishes. For our mains, I had the Unadon, which was really tasty, but also really beautifully prepared as you can see in the photo. My partner had the Wagyu Gyudon which was a really warm, comforting dish. 

One of the best moments of our experience was Bowen's pleas to try the marble soda. I had never heard of it, so I was kind of reluctant to try it. But Bowen was so excited and proud about serving the "good stuff" and brought out a bottle to kind of show us what it was all about. We got a bottle and it was certainly worth it. If you go, you really do have to try it. 

At the end of the day, you can really feel Bowen's heart in the food and the experience. It was the highlight of our day.

I was so hungry I forgot to take a photo before I began! Amazing food, best scallops I've ever had, and a unique experience. Bowen is an amazing chef and this is one of a kind menu. This was their 28 day dried New York Strip!

Identity crisis. 

Bowen Bistro has a bit of an identify crisis. I get the Asian fusion thing, but there are also standouts on the menu that seem way out of place (New Orleans salmon, Spaghetti and meatballs). 

Upon entering, there is a marquee that says "Fine Dining"; however places that are actually fine dining, don't need to announce it. On the table, the salt and pepper are cradled in a kitschy chef character. Not a problem, but not fine dining.  

There is a section called crepe omelets, I asked what makes them crepe and the server said, they are just omelets. No problem, but why include "crepe" in the name. 

I had the wagyu omelet ($16), it was really tasty. Their dishes are stand alone, which I am fine with, but there are no al a carte sides that you can order. 

Bowen (the chef/owner) came out to greet us, which is a nice touch. He's a young guy and really nice! I hope he can lose the seriousness of the restaurant and just make it young and fun like him! Lean into the kitsch!
Loved the food!  It really was amazing.  The only issue was that it still looks so much like Starbucks.  The interior really needs a makeover to get rid of that feel.  Nice job on the food!

Food quality very good
Ambience very good soft jazz...lighting...decor a 10
Service superb
Price....too high for area and portions
Dessert was not up to par....looked like store bought...not made there.

Very disappointed! For a restaurant that has a "Chef" who doesn't even know how to cook for people with food allergies! He doesn't even know what his ingredients contain! This place will send someone to the hospital soon enough. I'm just very shocked and disappointed.

Bowen, it was a pleasure last night when we ate dinner at Bowen Bistro. My kids were so excited to meet you and dine at your place, especially after watching you and cheering you on as a local celebrity chef. With much anticipation, you did not disappoint!  We ate the Surf and Turf with Filet Mignon and Shrimp, Yukon Gold Mashed Potatoes with Multi Vegetable Purée that looked like a rainbow on our plates.  In addition, the desserts are sumptuous and not to be missed either; we each ordered a different one!  I'm also looking forward to you having your liquor license next week so I can have a glass of wine with dinner. We look forward to many future visits!

The best fine dining fusion restaurant ! The NY strip was cooked perfectly medium rare and the desserts are the bomb! I felt lucky to meet celebrity chef Bowen at the end! Definitely gonna come back! Highly recommend!!!!!

The apps were really good, but it seemed a little weird that each app came out individually, as we shared them it wasn't a problem. But then there was a 30 minute wait until the entrees came. And again, each came out individually. My son was done his meal before mine came out, and then I was almost finished before the next 2 meals came out. And some of the food was cold while others were hot. The food was actually good, but the kitchen needs a lot of work to run smoothly. Not an enjoyable experience.

I have been to Bowen Bistro twice (one lunch and one dinner). The food was very good both times. The Hawaiian Avocado Tartare was creative and refreshing;  the Sukiyaki Wagyu Gyudon was an ultimate comfort food on a cold day; the Truffle Four-Cheese Ravioli was creamy and tasty. The service was okay, but some things remain to be worked out. Don't tell a table you can't do something "because you expect so many more people to come" (they never did show up).  Unfortunately, it is right now not a restaurant I plan to take visitors to (given the prices, it needs Purdue visitor business). The setup with two unprotected doors that let cold air in, the lighted billboard over the bar,  windows all around with most of them looking at a gas station and people pressing their noses against the glass, make the environment uninviting. Some of these issues can be addressed and hopefully they will.

I love their dessert soooooooooooooooo
 Much.
The service is sooooooooo good!
The environment of the restaurant is sooooooo good!

I dined at Bowen Bistro today for lunch and my experience was considerably better than these other reviews. I had the sukiyaki wagyu dish which had amazing flavors and presentation. We shared the truffle waffle fries with garlic aioli appetizer and all members of my family loved it. My daughter had the chicken Marsala. She loved it; it came with a delicious side of buttermilk mashed potatoes and puréed cauliflower (which he made on one of the Master Chef episodes last year as well). My wife had a zucchini pasta dish that was light and tasty. We all shared two of the desserts ( Black Truffle Hazelnut Mousse Cake and Red Velvet Mousse Cake) which were very good but less amazing than the entrees. Reasonably priced for the high quality.

We ate there last night with another couple. The experience was great the food was outstanding and I highly recommend giving them a try. The only downside was the wine selection was a little bit small but it was made up with the quality of food. The pricing was great and again the overall experience was outstanding

This is very cool and upscale fine dining restaurant! We ordered the filet mignon and shrimp ceviche it was more than amazing! If you are looking for a new experience Bowen bistro will be your first choice! The celebrity chef Bowen is a very creative and nice guy! We will be back!

Just had dinner here tonight -- the waitresses did a good job and were very nice; however, the food and wait time was unsatisfactory. The Gyoza was good; but, when it came to our entrees, there was a lot left to be desired. The chicken in the omelette and wrap tasted extremely processed (like McDonald's consistency). The salmon and the shrimp that accompanied it, were both undercooked and under-seasoned. Additionally, the dishes were served one at a time with a 20-minute lag between the first and last dish -- resulting in the initial dishes being cold. Dishes were overpriced given the quality of food. We had high expectations; hopefully they can turn things around quickly.

This is a new, locally owned restaurant started by a young, but very talented chef. I had the truffle ravioli and lobster bisque and both were fantastic. Came here with a big group and we all loved the dishes we ordered. Some aspects, like the decor would make me question if I would consider it fine dining, but the food lived up to it. The service was fantastic. The chef came out and introduced himself and shared his remarkable story. He makes you want to see this place succeed. I would highly recommend!!

This restaurant needs some time to get up and running. It took 40 min just to get our appetizers. After waiting longer we finally asked about when our main courses would be ready. They had not even started them yet! They also can't serve alcohol yet. I may try the place again in a few months. But, right now I would not go back.

reviews.text:
Sadly, Kibu Cafe is now gone. Kibu was my favorite place in town for Korean dishes and I miss the sweet little lady who always took our orders... It was bittersweet to hear that this new Korean restaurant opened up in the exact same location, but I'm glad I tried this place out anyways because everything was SO DELICIOUS. I was the only customer there because Purdue was on winter break, but I'm curious to know how busy this place is going to be during the school year. (Let's hope they do reservations)

Ordered the Dol Sot Bibimbap (rice, meat, veggie & egg in a stone bowl) and LA Galbi (beef short rib with bones), and they were both perfect. And yes, they serve Banchan (medley of tiny side dishes). Their seaweed soup was also very flavorful and delicious.

Can't wait to come back and try the Hae Mul Pa Jeon (seafood savory pancake), Bul Go Gi (marinated beef) and grilled pork belly because those are also staples! The interior was also remodeled and has that cozy-yet-chic farmhouse feel. The servers were very polite and attentive, and I enjoyed listening to K-Pop while I basically inhaled my meal. SO GOOD.
The food was great! There wasn't too many choices though. Worth to try. Will definitely go agai
So tasty!! I think this is my favorite korean place in town. I got the beef fried rice and the beef + onion combo was so flavorful! The beef was also the thinner, fattier type which I LOVE.
Damso is the best Korean restaurant in campus. I loved Galbitang, jeyukbokkeum, and  jju kkumi bokkeum. It was very tasty. When I visit the campus I always  go here for korean food.

Came here thinking it was still Kibu. Surprised that this business has not changed their sign outside.  Ordered the sulung tang and kalbi tang.  The kalbitang was ok.  The sulung tang had little to no meat.  My friend politely complained about his two tablespoons of meat.  The server told the owner.  The owner sent the server back with this reply. " I put enough meat in the soup, tell him to fish around for the meat".  My friend then FISHES out all the meat and shows there is only two tablespoons worth.  I've never heard a reply like that before.  The two soups were 15 dollars each.  Not a good value.  Will not be coming back. If you do go, don't order the sulung tang.  Maybe ask to see the owner and be nice? Hope this helps.

reviews.text:
You can't judge a book by its cover. It isn't obvious from the name that this is a sushi/Korean restaurant. And, if you drove past Purdue West you would assume that the restaurant is a casual takeout place. I had heard about a sushi place at Purdue West so I was looking for it. I was shocked to walk into a nicely decorated restaurant with table service. 

The lunch sushi rolls are named after buildings on campus and I had the Hall of Music roll (spicy crab roll) and the Stewart roll (spicy tuna) and they were both really good. They also have many Korean dishes such as bibimbap, Korean fried chicken, gamja tang, etc. Food arrived quickly so people on their lunch hour could easily have enough time for lunch.

There are weird hours during the summer, but we were able to come in for dinner on a weekday night.  It definitely looks like we should visit during lunch for the sushi roll specials! 

The sushi rolls we ordered were okay, but I have had better in the area. Some of the pieces of sashimi tasted as though it's been thawed out. I wouldn't come back for dinner, but I'd probably check out lunch.

I was pleased to find this asian themed restaurant close to Purdue's campus. I enjoyed this place for several reasons, the first being the variety in their menu. I ordered the bibimbap in a stone bowl, which allowed me to scrape the bottom for those crunchy bits of rice. However, the flavor was a bit lacking in my opinion. The complimentary miso soup was a surprise on a chilly day, and also quite tasty. I look forward to trying this place again!
Hope you guys never order to go！so awful！ I order a soup to go, when I came home and opened it. You can see the picture. What's it? Are you humiliated me??? Worst restaurants at west Lafayette‍‍‍‍‍

Takeout review:The wings here - more korean than japanese in style- are outstanding but hidden in the menu.  They're meaty, crunchy and loaded with sauce.  Better than bonchon in chicago in my opinion.

We also ordered asparagus roll, which was just right, and eel roll.  See the pic for the wings tho...

On second venture we ordered more of their lunch special rolls, dragon roll and sashimi / sushi combos.  Pics attached!

For the Purdue/West Lafayette, IN area, this place is fantastic. Very decent sushi and basic Korean food options. Service is friendly and the kitchen is efficient. Maybe drink at home, though, since the beer is a bit too expensive. Best deal is to eat here at lunch when they have bento boxes.

If you live near the west side of the Purdue campus, this is also one of the only food options in town--either this or Papa John's Pizza.

My husband and I ordered chicken teriyaki bento lunch box.This meal was really tasty and satisfying. A delicious Miso soup was also served before main meal. They also have good deal specials for lunch.

Delicious! We are from the Twin Cities and if my son chooses Purdue this will be our go to place. Enjoyed every bite: chicken wings to start perfect and wanted more, then we ordered hot tea worth it, lunch rolls number four, number five, number seven, and number 11. Also one deluxe role: treasure Island. Yes! So good.
One of my favorite asian in Purdue but they only open only on some days. I like the lunch combo, picked Stewart and Krannert roll. Their bento box is superb

One day I received a takeout menu on my car in a parking garage. I am always looking to try new sushi places in town, so I figured I would give it a try. This is by far the best sushi place I have found in town. They have a variety of unique rolls and sushi bowls. They were not overly busy when we went for dinner, but do not let that deter you as the food is wonderful. Our server was so kind and our sushi did not take long. I will be back!

The food tastes great: fresh and flavoured just right. 
Not very Japanese I must say, it is more Americanized. Still the food is pretty good. 
Service is welcoming and comforting, environment is clean. Lighting might be a bit dark, but during the day it's fine. 
Price is a bit high for the quality and portion, but it is better than most Japanese restaurants around Purdue. 
Overall worth trying, be ready to pay a bit more than you expected.

Came for lunch before noon on a weekday after class was out. People started streaming in at about 12-12:15. Was surprised. Very nice decor, comfortable seats, chic place. Good service.

I ordered a fried tofu appetizer and the sauce was delicious. Miso was also pretty good. 

My bulgogi bento was ok. Meat could have been either flavored more or cooked less. I liked the onions mixed in. The roll with it was just ok...too much rice, though. The salad was terrible. Dressing was mayo-based. Not like a normal Japanes/fusion ginger dressing. Bad. 

Wife enjoyed all three of her rolls a lot. I tried them all and thought they had too much rice or no texture. And the fish was ok, not great.

It may be one of the better Asian restaurants around campus, but there are several better ones around town and I will likely stick with those.

This is the best sushi place ever! The rolls kept getting better and better. We had the Snow White roll,Indiana roll, sexy roll, sweet Hawaiian, and the rainbow,they were all astonishing. The waitress was nice. Great atmosphere. Pretty awesome over all. Definitely recommend!

My husband and I just moved from Okinawa, Japan. My husband is now a soccer coach with Fishya, a Korean and Japanese restaurant, sponsoring the team. We had a table of 7. Fastest service I have ever had at a restaurant that wasn't fast food. 

We ordered the bulgogi (spicy of course), Ramen (which we requested to also be spicy), Gyoza, California roll, and my favorite the Dragon Roll. Eel is my absolute favorite sushi. The ramen was different than what I am used to in Japan. There was corn in it which gave it a distinct flavor. 
My husband said Yummytime has better bulgogi per meat and juiciness ratio.
But for sushi. Hands down the absolute best I have had so far since moving here. I will come back when I am craving sushi.  I shared with my 6 year old son and we wanted more! 

We are truly lucky to live next to Purdue, where different cultures collide, and we can have a little taste from our home we had in Japan.

Fishya has a great classy atmosphere with light jazz playing in the background. I thought it might be more pricy than regular restaurants around town, but to my surprise I definitely got my money's worth here! We ordered the sushi roll lunch special, 3 rolls for $11. It's such a great deal.

Foods are nice and staffs are really kind. 
I definitely say the best sushi in town.
You guys should try Korean chicken wings. It is dope!!!!
Great service.  Food is good but we're from Chicago so hey not the greatest Asian / Japanese I've had

We went to this place to try some Korean food. My husband loves soon dobu so he wanted to try it here. But unfortunately they don't serve it anymore there. So he had Gamja tang instead. The soup was good and flavorful. I had Galbi tang and it was very tasty. We shared Galbi also. Galbi was very meaty. I think their Galbi was the meatiest among other Korean restaurants in West Lafayette. I liked the decor of restaurant. Our server was very friendly. Overall we really liked this restaurant.
My lunch bento box is not bad, my friend's bibimbap is amazing. The appetizers are fine, rice cake sauce is not thick enough, takoyaki is a little pricey. Will come back for bibimbap.

Dont get me wrong...the FOOD IS GOOD! BUT the service is bad. The waitress was chatting with the sushi chef for a long time and ignoring us. Our water wasnt filled and it took at least 2 to 3 attempts to get her attention. On the other side, her colleague was bussing other tables tirelessly while she chatted away. Props to that waiter for his hardwork.

reviews.text:
Up side: Maru is delicious and before Covid, we dined there frequently. They have soy paper, which is a requirement for me, and I particularly like the Purdue roll.

But as a heads up: as of today, at least, they're doing take out only. Good on y'all for keeping employees safe and masked!
Love Maru. Even for carry out their quality is top notch!  Whose Brain is our favorite appetizer!

My sister ordered some maru sushi today for pickup. I've only tried it once before, long time ago, but it was really flavorful and well made I thought this time! Would order some for myself too next time :)

I always order the yakisoba dish and ask for extra spicy. Sometimes they mix sauce in and bring it to me spicy (which I prefer) or they give me sriracha to do myself. (Not we preferred but still okay!) I'm obsessed! It's good every damn time. It's also a serious pregnancy craving of mine!

I've also tried a lot of the sushi and the fried gyoza. Everything has been super yummy!!

A bit disappointed in this place. Food was very sub-par despite the good reviews. I ordered the Vegetable Udon and California Roll. Sushi was average, it tasted like something you would buy at a grocery store but definitely did the job for the price. The vegetable udon however was pretty bland and the vegetables were over cooked. The portion size was great, but flavor and texture were lacking. Might try the sushi again (since it is a Sushi place), but likely won't get too experimental with the other menu options.

Maru is a good sushi spot that's conveniently located near campus.  My boyfriend and I came on a Sunday evening and it wasn't too busy! 

There are a lot of rolls to choose from, but we went with shrimp tempura, chauncey roll, purdue roll, and sunday morning roll.  While we waited, the server brought us pickled cucumbers and pickled daikon, along with miso soup! All delicious!

The sushi rolls weren't too big, but four rolls was just enough for us two. 
 They were all really good but the chauncey roll was our favorite!

The prices are pretty reasonable and I would say this is a sold 4 restaurant! I would come back for a quick sushi fix.
We hit this place after getting piercings done at New Breed. What a fantastic place! They made the rolls on about 15 minutes and everything was fantastic.
Great prices, great food, and the staff were wonderful. My favorite place to get sushi

Friendly staff, super quick service, and delicious, fresh, affordable sushi...what more could a girl ask for?? 

I discovered Maru my first weekend in West Lafayette and plan to be a regular now that I've witnessed its greatness! You can choose from basic rolls which are around $4-6, and speciality rolls ranging from $6 to $12. There is a large menu of appetizer and non-sushi entree items as well. Both the shrimp dumplings and teriyaki tofu were 100% amazing! 

The staff are welcoming, friendly, and incredibly fast. Plus you get a cup of miso soup included with your meal if you dine in! If you like high quality sushi for a good price, look no further. BONUS: there's a frozen yogurt shop right next door

All around average, though some aspects border on the bad side. Having tried several of the Lafayette area's sushi offerings thus far, this is the worst I've tasted yet. Pieces are smaller than what you would get at other venues, and the ingredients variously do not taste as fresh or otherwise more bland, by one reason or another. Granted, those better sushi places charge $2-$10 more for most of their equivalent or comparable "specialty" rolls, so I guess the price in this case reflects the quality. You would be spending, for example, $16-$22 on two large or specialty rolls at Katana or Sushi Don, whereas here, you could get two of said-rolls for about $10-$20. That might be a deal for some, but I personally would rather pay the slightly higher price for good sushi, rather than go to a restaurant to eat gas station sushi. 

Their other food isn't that good, either. I tried the yaki udon my last visit, for instance, and it was all around bland, like the sushi, without much flavour to it other than no-frills soy sauce and too-much-stir-fry-oil. For $2 more, you could get almost twice as many noodles and in a delicious, mildly-spicy sauce from Katana up on Sagamore. 

They give you a "free" appetizer of miso soup and vegetables, similar to Sushi Don. But whereas Sushi Don will give you a delicious salad, Maru's vegetables were a few pieces of raw, cold broccoli with a vaguely-vinegar-like flavour, and raw shaved carrots, turnips, or something like that with an unpleasantly acrid taste. I was at a loss to explain why they would serve something so unpalatable, until I saw another reviewer claim that these things are "pickled," which they certainly are not -- just raw vegetables briefly splashed in a vinegar solution. 

The miso soup was also inferior to Sushi Don's, in my opinion -- it could be a matter of taste, but I prefer my miso to not taste and smell like a pungent/stinky variety of tofu. I do not know if it is a regular occurrence, or where exactly the smell was coming from, but the entire restaurant smelled very strongly of sulphur my last visit there, like rotten eggs or sewage. The only other time I ever smelled something similar was in the Jimmy John's nearby some time ago, and given that they don't use eggs over in that venue, I am inclined to think it has to do with West Lafayette's notoriously overloaded sewer system given you "backdrafts" now and then in some of the Chauncey village establishments. Wherever the smell was coming from, it ensured that I could not manage to choke down the miso.

Service is not great, either. I had a family seated by me my last visit, for instance, but then they were told to move -- no ands, ifs, or buts about, and no apologies given -- for what seemed to be the servers forgetting that they had a large party coming in who would need the space. I was rushed out the door for the same reason, being in the way by their fault. All the while, a bus boy would sneak over to your table and spirit away your dishes, often forgetting to ask whether or not you were done with them. 

One more thing: they either regularly or selectively tack on a gratuity to your bill. My last visit was the first time I was paying the bill while here, and I noticed that, between the two items (the yaki udon and the Sunday Morning roll) plus tax, the final price was about $17. I give them my card, and they come back with a receipt citing $18.35, adding on at least a dollar. Yeah, I don't play that game -- if I am grateful for your food (as gratuity implies), I will give you something extra. You don't automatically help yourself to gratuities. For that reason, more than the mediocre food, I would not come back here.

Maru never disappoints when I go. Authentic Japanese food right down to the rice. Ive been to Japan and fell in love with Japanese Food so im so lucky to have a place like this that is close to Purdue and very affordable. I love their sushi but they have great food as-well.

Excellent sushi! Ate here as a student, came back as an alumni (after travel to Japan and living in a few different places in the US) and I STILL love this place! Staff is friendly, service is fast, and the sushi is incredibly fresh with awesome variety on the menu. This will always be a favorite!

I was so pleasantly surprised when I came here for the first time recently. Maru easily has the best sushi on or near campus, and their dining area is now actually fairly spacey. I have come here for lunch on one occasion, and for dinner about three times now. 

The service here is quick and efficient. Within minutes of ordering, they bring out the miso soup. It's not the most fantastic miso I've ever had, but hey, it's free. I also typically order edamame, and it's great and tastes very fresh. 

I usually order some combination of two rolls as far as sushi goes as my meal. This is where I was very pleasantly surprised - it is incredibly good. I really like the Playboy roll in particular. The fish tastes fresh, the rice is perfect, and the other components just make sense. They have a great selection of rolls, and chances are if you're even just relatively open to the idea of sushi, you will find something you like here. It all tastes fresh and professional, and I really enjoy eating here.

The only downfall is the price - I know that sushi isn't exactly fast food, but you can easily rack up a $30 bill if you're not careful here. I usually stick to dinner here for that reason, and only every once in a while. If it were a little easier on the wallet, I'd probably be here every week. 

Overall though, if you like sushi and you are in the Purdue area, Maru is a must-try.
Good fresh sushi. Good service. I cannot remember exactly what I ordered, but I remember my wife ordered a teriyaki chicken dinner. The food came out extremely fast.
Their carry-out is very smooth and fast. The variety of sushi they have is massive and the fish tastes very fresh. Love ordering from here!

Food is pretty good and everyone is nice and accommodating. My meal for the lunch box and the unagi roll was $17 and it was decently sized and filling. I've been a couple times and I've never had a bad experience.

First off, the service was excellent! They greeted us, kept up with refilling our water and kept asking if we needed anything more. They were very kind. The sushi and sides (miso soup, broccoli, etc.) were fantastic. Where they fall is in their entrees. I ordered yaki soba noodles with chicken and the first thing I can smell is ketchup. And that's all it smelt like. Ketchup. It really was the worst yaki soba I have ever eaten in my time here. I recommend them for sushi and service. Don't order an entree.
i haven't had much sushi in my life, but i've recently grown to like it a lot and this was definitely the best tuna roll i've ever had. thank you and will be back! :)

First time trying sushi from this restaurant. I ordered the Playboy Roll, based on the recommendations I had read... It was fantastic!

I will certainly be ordering from here again.

I've been debating whether or not to rate Maru as a 3 or 4-star restaurant, but ultimately decided on a 4-star review for their quality food, great friendly service, clean atmosphere and overall pleasant experience 

As a college student, our budgets are tight, therefore I do not go to Maru unless I'm splurging. This is why I was stuck between rating Maru as a three or four stars. However, your money paying for is quality food.

I ordered the "I love Tuna" roll, which is $10.95, and a vegetable udon noodle soup for $8.95. I was moderately hungry, and this meal filled me up, however, the total was over $20. The roll itself was delicious, with fresh juicy tuna, and the udon soup cooked well with a variety of spinach, broccoli, and greens with flavorful Udon noodles and soup. 

The service was on time, the servers were hospitable, and there is complimentary miso soup before sushi. 

I recommend visiting Maru for a more intimate setting, as space is limited. Or for visiting friends/family who enjoy quality sushi.

reviews.text: Looooved the udon here when I lived here while in graduate school. Perfect antidote for the unpleasant frosty winters of Indiana. The broth was so flavorful and I loved how you sat kinda on the floor like an authentic Japanese restaurant.
The food is decent, but they've changed a lot. And not for the better. The menu is different. The prices are higher. The staff is alright. But it's not as good as it used to be.

My wife, fluent japanese speaker, loves Heisei.  It attracts many japanese nationals, and people with kids like us.  The young man doing hosting and our server were fantastic, and we enjoyed the fried chicken and sashimi very much.

Visiting the area for my cousins graduation from Purdue and came here for dinner. It was around 8:45 and it was really busy, but we had reservations so were seated right away.

Service here was friendly, but the food did take awhile to come out. The soup, salads, and sushi/sashimi came out first. The fish here was very fresh and pretty good. Two of us got their dinner combo sets. This came out last, about 30 mins after ordering. However, portion size was very large, and most of it was pretty good. The combos do come with a stir fry of vegetables though which was basically a waste of space in the bento box. The tempura was slightly soggy. It also mentions a "fruit salad", which was just a slice of cantaloupe. Overall, an ok Japanese restaurant for the price.

This review is a little late so I cannot remember what sushi I had but I loved it.  Delicious.  My daughter had a curry and was craving it again but they are closed on Sundays, which makes me sad.  Oh well.  Cannot wait to go back.  GO HERE!

This is my absolute favorite Japanese restaurant in the area. They offer traditional dishes like cold soba noodles and sake don to bento boxes, in addition to a variety of sushi. They also have traditional-style floor seating, which is always fun. I recommend the green tea soba with tempura, udon noodle soups, and sake don. 

Side note: they oddly close at 1:30pm for lunch.
Different experience than other sushi places I've been- but the food was still good and the staff was very attentive

Used to be my most recommended curry around Lafayette. Japanese style curry, large amount with decent price below 10. However, they raised the price few months ago. 3+1 star due to how it wasn't pricey before.

Very good Sushi and very reasonably priced. Authentic short tables to sit at if you want the very Asian experience.  Ate here with my daughter,who is a student at Purdue, because she wanted to try it and it was AOK with me as I am inclined to enjoy Asian cuisine having been to Japan as a Toyota business man. I was passing through towards Michigan on business and it was a welcome stop.

Heisei has been a standard in West Lafayette for many years. We were excited when they finally reopened at their current location!  If you are looking for truly authentic Japanese fare and sushi, this is your place!  They also have traditional seating for an authentic dining experience!  Love the New Spider Roll too!  It's sooooo good!

We've gone to Heisei many times over the years. I hadn't been in a few months but I had the mackerel combination dinner tonight and it's so good. The potstickers (gyōza) are very nice. If you haven't tried mackerel I recommend it. Their tempura is lovely. The vegetables were delicious. I lived in Japan for five years, lived (and learned to cook) with a Japanese family, worked as a Japanese-English translator. I know Japanese food, and the food at Heisei is excellent. I like the new setting (they moved a year or two ago); it's very spacious and relaxing. We were there tonight with little kids, and it's very family friendly.
The best japanese restaurant in West Lafayette~ The environment and taste are both very authentic.

Got the to tonkatsu ramen and chicken karaage. Also got a bit of nigiri to test it out. The ramen was a bit too salty but good nonetheless if you're trying to satisfy your Japanese ramen craving. The karaage was pretty good, with the perfect amount of crunch and tender of the chicken. The nigiri really good, almost reminded me of being back home in Los Angeles!

I'm not sure about options for ramen in West Lafayette - they seemed a bit limited when I had a craving and was doing search - but the dishes here were a little less than impressive. For the price, one would expect some richer broth, better cuts of meat, and higher quality noodles involved. Unfortunately, that wasn't the case. 

The tonkotsu, normally a rich pork bone broth created after a marathon of simmering, was flat and salty. It didn't have the usual signs of fresh-made creation: oils and fat bubbles or robust flavor. Instead, it just had a creamy color and had some spices lazily added.

I loved Heisei in its previous, decades-long incarnation in the Payless shopping center. Once it fled West Lafayette, we were left with a void that was shortly filled by Katana. Heisei has been back for a while now and I finally went after having become a regular at Katana.

The restaurant space is modern, bright, chic. All solid surfaces, so it's a little loud in there. The sushi counter is pretty nice. Wooden table around an interesting sushi setup. I liked the look of the place.

Staff were ok. A little slow but not that bad. 

I ordered the sushi & sashimi combo lunch. It was served with both salad and miso. Lucky me! The salad was very poor. They either don't dry the lettuce or use a very watery dressing. It's the classic "pool" at the bottom of the salad bowl. Not good. The miso was nice and tasty. I applaud that effort.

The lunch came with four sashimi, four nigiri and a small roll half cucumber, half chopped fish of some sort.

Sashimi was so-so. I liked the octopus and clam but the actual fish was not as fresh as I expect from a good sushi place. Nigiri was the same story. Just blah.

Sushi roll came with Nori on the outside. Who's still doing that? The roll was the quality I would expect from crappy college campus sushi places.

On the whole, this fish was just not *nearly* as high quality as Katana and it was not as fresh. One piece was actually semi-frozen still. Attention to detail. 

I would suggest Katana over Heisei for sure. Prices are about the same.

This place is legendary. I am told that its history dates back to a decision wise Subaru executives made back in the day to hire in a sushi chef to provide landlocked Hoosiers with quality sushi. Today the skills of the staff are indeed apparent in every bite. The menu is expansive, with noodles, rice balls, bento boxes, entrees, and more in addition to sushi selections. 

The house sake is good quality at a great price. We have eaten here several times and tried various sushi orders, rice balls, bento boxes, and udon, in addition to appetizers including various seafood and seaweed salad and a beef tongue special. Everything has been consistently excellent. 

The aesthetic is spare and a bit sterile, in keeping with what you might find in Japan. We have had efficient and courteous service in our experiences at Heisei. The kitchen does tend to get behind on busy nights; the servers have been apologetic about that, and we have found the food well worth the wait.
They changed the order system that you have to order and pay before being seated. The system is so stupid and you have stand there and think about what to eat. Not recommend anymore.

I'm a big fan of ramen when it comes to Japanese food.

This had been one of my favorite places around Purdue that serve Japanese food. Their sushi was the best in West Lafayette at the time I wrote this review.

I wished they had a bigger space so that a big group could reserve a large table. Once, I tried to reserve a table for a large group, and they could not take it. too bad.

Make sure to come for their dinner menu, which I found much better than their lunch menu
Good selection of Japanese dishes. Had Katsu curry, sukiyaki, and got unajyu tonight. Clean restaurant, good service

Yum! Cute Japanese restaurant and was a lot bigger and nicer than how it looks on the outside. They have sushi bar seating, tables, and the nice Japanese tables that your feet sink into the floor. Two of us got seated right away and the sushi bar and were greeted nicely by the sushi chefs. The menu items are a little pricey, but I think it would be a deal to come at lunch time. We got a variety of rolls and the katsu curry. Everything was delicious! The customer service was also outstanding. We got our waters refilled, plates cleared promptly, and the chefs made sure we were okay. Definitely coming back with my friends to try the lunch specials! They also have good daily deals as well :)

reviews.text:
This review is for the food and the service provided during this Covid-19 issue. 

We ordered from Hunter's using their online order form that we found on their FB page. The ordering process was very simple and a full menu, as well as beer, is available.  The order form gives you the opportunity to customize your sandwiches.  For example "sauce on the side" is an option.  

We ordered the pub chicken sandwich with chips and the High 5 grilled cheese with waffle fries.   My wife got her sauce on the side and I was able to remove the provolone cheese and add bacon. We ordered and the website told us our order would be ready in 15 minutes and gave the instructions on how to pick up.  We arrived at the 15 minute mark, called to let them know we were there, and they brought our order right out. 

We drove to a local park to eat and our food was still hot and good as always!

Hunter's has done a good job of adjusting for the current situation.

Writing an update in regards to the COVID-19 adaption Hunter's Pub has made--I'm pretty impressed. I missed their darling nachos grande so we decided to order some for take out and Hunter's did several things right. They not only had the food warm and ready for us to pick up, they packed moist towelettes, napkins, plasticware, and did not skimp out on the food. The amount was as much as we would have if eating in. They seemed really appreciative of our support for their local business.

Decided to try this place out with my BF for some good take out after cooking at home for awhile and to support local businesses. This was our first time and we were looking forward to trying it out. The lady who took our order was very nice and the food was ready in less than 15 minutes. Then we checked our order and found out our half-pound, $11 boneless chicken appetizer only had 10 small chicken pieces. Maybe they were half a pound but I don't think so. We asked the lady and she said that it's always 10 wings to a order so I don't understand why they can't just write that on the menu instead of "half-pound" of chicken as it's misleading. The burger and fries were pretty good so I didn't want to review them low due to how good service was and the food was not bad. Just very disappointed by the chicken as it was an appetizer that didn't come with any additional sides besides celery.

So new owner at Hunters. I'm really liking what I see. Joy is very involved. I see her cleaning and scrubbing and asking questions. We chatted today and her statement that really won me over, "I want Hunters to be the place our customers deserve."  I'm looking forward to the great changes that are in store at Hunters. As always solid food, great beer selection and well stocked bar

Ordered tenderloin- prime rib sandwich and a prime rib steak dinner . I called them back as soon as I got home and realized this is NOT a prime rib . It's more like an old rib eye . The Cesar salad was less then good due to the amount of water in it . The tenderloin was over cooked  and waffle fries . The prime rib sandwich was ok .. and had to feed 2 of us to make up for the bad steak . 
I called the place back to explain the problems and even sent a text to show him the pic and was only offered 2 -$5 gift cards for the next visit . ( even though the dinner was $19.99)  the baked potato was also old and brown . Very disappointed in the results and spending $45 on poor food .
Nice local place but the food is just average. The catfish was like eating a slab of salt. The grilled veggies were good. Nice selection of beer. Staff was friendly.

Solid pub. Stopped in for their "Meatloaf Thursday"; meatloaf was phenomenal, and House green beans were great. Attractive, clean interior. Service was warm and friendly. If you are in the area, stop in; you won't be disappointed.

I've now been here three times, and I feel like I can give them a solid 4 stars.  We discovered that if you sit on the left side of the self-seat restaurant, it's the "drinking" area, so the waitstaff doesn't see you.  We ended up leaving in a hungry huff, but later realized it was kind of on us.  That said, the restaurant probably should've noticed that two people were sitting there with no drinks and looking around....or put up a sign that says "Bar service this way, restaurant service that way."  I took off half a star for this mix up.

The second and third times were solid.  I got the same dish both times, and was pleased with the portion size; I walked out super full.  The onion rings are large and battered, which I appreciate more that the crumb coating.  The chicken parm sandwich was yummy.  Spouse had a hamburger the first time, and a frisco melt the second time. In his words, 'They're okay, dawg."  Which, translated, means, "They were okay, but not so good that I won't try something else next time."

The other half star was taken off because of the way they label their bathrooms.  The men's room is labeled "Hunter," and the women's room is labeled "Hunted."  We live in a post-#MeToo era, and this seems pretty tone-deaf.  I don't really want a bar reminding me that it's a place where I could be "hunted" by their other clientele.

Hunters is a mixed bag for me, but I think four stairs is fair based on overall food quality, value, beer/food selection, and furnishings. I've been here six or eight times over the years and decided to finally write a review. 

I had the black-n-blue burger, well done, with fries. The burger was cooked through without being burnt. The blue cheese was sharp and added good taste and texture. Lettuce and tomato garnish was super fresh. The bun was nothing spectacular, it did not hold up to the weight of the burger or my cutting the sandwich, but did its job and held the burger and toppings together. The fries were a disappointment. These were overcooked and lukewarm. Definitely had been sitting in the fry pile for a while and dried out. There is no excuse for a pub not serving fresh piping hot fries. A disappointment that should drop this review to three stars, but the quality of the second meal buoyed my score.

My partner had the chicken quesadilla dinner plate, which came with refried beans, rice, some lettuce and sour cream, and a side of salsa too spicy to eat. Very good dish and we had enough quesadilla left for a take home snack. The entire place seemed to be staffed with one bartender and two servers. They kept up with the full house remarkably well. Overall a good value for the price, both meals under $10. My partner got the usual overpriced soda but the server kept it full.

This pub draws mostly graduate students and the 40-65 year old crowd, local professionals and married folk on a dates or girls night out. There are exceptions, both younger and older, but it's definitely not a college bar. Hunters is a decent pub that benefits from its location, large menu, and lack of competition in this busy commuter corridor loaded with strip-mall and small businesses. The interior is nothing special: a lot of wood, TVs, and chalkboard signage. It's quite boring actually but the pre-geriatric crowd doesn't seem fazed in the slightest.

I'm not a fan, as four stars suggests, but Hunters is a safe bet. Hard to go wrong with this local establishment. Final verdict: 3.5 stars and I'm rounding up due to value. Give me hot fresh fries, and it's four stars fo realz, yo!
No, thank you. I left immediately after seeing the bathroom signs. My buffalo chicken wrap was fine... but then I vomited after I saw those signs so the food really isn't my issue at all.

This pub is a staple in West Lafayette and is a great to place to go for lunch or dinner. There are plenty of TV's to watch sports and enjoy the big game. The food menu is very extensive and should be able to please any taste buds. My favorite here is the fish and chips (catfish fingers and fries). Be sure to get the fries cajun style for extra zing. In addition to the great food, they have plenty of beer, wine and liquor options. 

The servers and bartenders are great here and are very attentive.  They take very good care of you and keep your drinks full. If you are in town to see the Boilers, visiting friends/family or just to hang out...make sure you stop by Hunter's to grab some food and a drink! You won't regret it.

This is a dive local to Lafayette and they have great food! I don't usually do fish anywhere on the planet but HP's breaded catfish dinner is just to die for. It tastes the same every time and enough for two if you get the 2 piece meal.

Although it states this place is not good for kids, no where does it state you must be 21 to eat here.   Spent an hour trying to decide where to have dinner.  Not an easy feet with multiple food allergies 

No where on yelp OR THE main page does it state this.  

What a waste of our time
Change your bathroom signs. Seriously. Like someone else said, it's disgusting and tone deaf to suggest that women should be "hunted". Really uncool.

We've been here several times and, generally both the food and service are good. They have a very large menu so some things will be pretty good and others will be not so good. The menu is less creative and the food isn't as good as Digby's, but if you are looking for a solid, no frills, meal then this is a good place to eat.

Great spot for locals and Purdue students! The prices are super reasonable and the staff is funny and attentive. Their fries are fantastic! One small thing is that the bathroom signs are kinda sexist with the men's room being labeled "Hunter" and the women's says "The Hunted". It's 2018, that's gross. But the food, atmosphere, drink specials, and deals are great!

I wish I lived in West Lafayette - I would come here all the time. Food was sooo good and the portions were very, very generous. The pork tenderloin sandwich (three little pigs) was perhaps one of the best I've had. Ordered it with waffle fries which were also delicious.  Let me also recommend quesadillas for the appetizer.

Hunter's Pub on the West Side is my favorite place to grab a good burger and fries. There are several other tasty items on the menu - which has a ton of variety. Sandwiches, Mexican food, lots of appetizers and more complete dinners are also available. 

Make no mistake, this is a sports bar. Several TVs have different games playing and the staff will gladly change a channel to play your game for you. 

Food is consistently good and service is fast and friendly.

This is a popular local place to grab a bite to eat. Service is always great and very friendly. Having said that, food is good, but isn't exactly unique. That's probably why I like Hunters Pub: there are no surprises.

I'm a huge fan of Hunters. I'm vegetarian and Hunters is one of few restaurants with multiple options in this town. Our server is always friendly. The drink specials are amazing. And the price is on point. My meal usually costs $9 and I have leftovers for the next day. The caveat is that it's greasy bar food but they are good for that and don't claim to be anything else.

reviews.text: MY FAVORITE RESTAURANT ON THE ENTIRE EARTH. The food here is amazing every single time! My fiancé and I love to come here for special occasion date nights and we always tell people that it is one of our favorite restaurants ever. We talked about it so much that our families joined us for a meal for a celebration we were having. They all enjoyed the food as well! My family is from out of town, and they were raving about their meal and how they couldn't wait to go back. They still talk about how good the food was! We always joke that we would make the 3 hour drive just for La Scala's food! It's that good!! I seriously cannot recommend this restaurant enough. I've only ever dined inside, and the atmosphere is really nice. It's quiet, intimate, and cozy. I would love to dine outside as well though! They have a really pretty patio area with lights. I can't wait to go back soon! I would also like to add that I am gluten free and they have great options for me, including gluten free dinner rolls!

Thank goodness for La Scala! As a born-and-raised Chicago girl, I require a higher than normal amount of cheese and carbs for daily survival (preferably in the form of pizza, but pasta will also suffice). I admit that I was a bit worried about finding good Italian food after moving to Indiana...but not anymore!

When you walk in the door of La Scala, the first thing that hits you is the ambiance. Like Pavlov's dogs, I've been conditioned to salivate when I hear the crooning voice of Sinatra, especially when combined with the smell of garlic in the air. Add in the warm and cozy atmosphere, friendly staff, and ample seating (indoor and out, weather permitting), and I was in heaven. I loooove their menu; I seriously have a list of about 10 items still to try, and had a lot of difficulty choosing which one to start with. Everything sounds SO good! On my first trip I had the pumpkin mac & cheese, with their apple cider cocktail drink. So much comfort food. It's like a hug on a plate! 

If you are looking for a great place to get that homecooked meal even if you're far from home, give La Scala a try. They're open for lunch and for dinner (they do close in between though, so be wary if you're looking for something between 2-5). They cater to special food restrictions, including gluten-free, so get on in there and eat!

Excellent dinner!  The menu is robust and great variety. The bread and olive oil is wonderful start to the meal. Each pasta comes with soup or salad. The entrees were plentiful. 

For entrees, my husband had the risotto and said it was outstanding!  I had the Miguel Angelo and was pleased. The sauce was a little thin but taste was delightful. My daughter had the gnocchi bolognese and loved it. 

Great restaurant right on the Lafayette square. Definitely make a reservation on a weekend as they were busy!  Always a good sign!

Can I just say how much I love that they have gluten-free options at the restaurant? Good, because I'm gonna. Italian food was my FAVORITE food before getting a gluten allergy. Now there are far and few dishes that I can enjoy at an Italian restaurant. Not anymore! La Scala is now my go-to place in Lafayette for gluten free pasta!

First of all, I love this building! Gothic archway and stained glass on the front entryway. Lovely outdoor seating area with the rustic charm of Italy itself. Did I also mention that they are farm to table and chef-owned? Yep, everything you could ever want to support in a local restaurant is here at La Scala!

I came here with some friends, and everyone LOVED their entrees and drinks. Definitely Try their lasagna. It's fresh, homemade and amazing! You also get your money's worth here. I couldn't finish all of my food, even though I wanted to. The server was very knowledgeable in what items were gluten-free, and if he didn't know he would go and ask the chef. Superb customer service. I can't wait for my next trip to Lafayette so I can sample more of what they have to offer for us gluten intolerant folks.

My best friend has raved about this place for years, but we had never tried it, so when we were picking a place to have a slightly belated Valentine's Day dinner (February 15th), I figured it was time to finally try La Scala.

The restaurant is small and intimate. I wouldn't really recommend it for groups. There are a few four seater tables, but it looked like most of the tables were for two. However, the tables are very close together (very European style), so if you're looking for a quiet place where you won't hear the conversations of people around you, this may not be the place for you. It wasn't too bad for us, although my chair was touching the chair of the woman behind me. The tables were lovely, set with white tablecloths and tea lights.

The meal starts with water an bread service. The bread does come with olive oil and spices for dipping (yum!), but the bread has olives in it, so if you're not an olive fan, be aware. You can pick most of them out if you want to though.

We didn't get any appetizers, though the shrimp and crab dip sounded really good (and then the table next to us ordered it, and it looked delicious, but my husband would never eat it and it was definitely too much for me!). I was torn between the seafood ravioli and the lobster & shrimp mac and cheese; our server recommended the mac and cheese, so that's what I went with. My husband ordered the pollo ripieno without the red pepper cream sauce.

My husband said his dish was very flavorful, even without the sauce. I absolutely LOVED the mac and cheese. The Grand Marnier cream sauce was lovely, the mozzarella on top was extra melty, and I thought the orange was a thoughtful (and tasty) touch. There was also way more seafood than I expected; there were whole shrimp, large chunks of lobster, and it seemed to be almost as much seafood as pasta!

Unfortunately, we had to cut our evening short (our babysitter called to say our youngest had gotten sick), but our server, Beau, was awesome about getting us the check quickly, boxing up the rest of my meal (I don't think I'd ever had someone else box up my leftovers for me before!), and getting me a cannoli to go (the cannoli was delicious, btw -- very smooth filling!).

Great food and great service makes La Scala a great choice!

Excellent food, excellent atmosphere, hit-or-miss service. Have celebrated valentine's day, multiple bridal shower/bachelorette dinners, birthdays, promotions, and more here. Have always enjoyed all the amazing food, and especially enjoy any of the tortellini dishes. The house sangria is really good.

La Scalia is always consistent with the quality of their meals. The whole atmosphere of the restaurant is very cozy and makes you feel like you aren't downtown. The food is delicious as well as the bread.

The food was fantastic. 
We had pastas - shrimp Alfredo and chicken asparagus in lemon cream.   Both came with large Caesar salads and crispy bread.

The patio is charming and tucked away so it is wind free.

The wine list is small but pleasant.

Too bad they close at 9pm.
When I'm in Lafayette LaScala is my choice.

I have been going here at least once every couple months and every time it's been great. They have a good selection of items on the menu, and the atmosphere is fancy and welcoming. The service is good and the overall experience is always enjoyable. One of the best Italian restaurants in the area for sure.

I have been here for dinner several times, but today I had lunch. Delicious! This might not seem like a typical lunch spot, but it is tasty and affordable...with options other than pasta. I had a cup of chicken vegetable soup and a Ceaser salad with bread, all for about $10. Local, fresh, friendly service and different. My friend had  an Italian veggie sandwich that she loved. Certainly worth supporting a great local restaurant.

First time here. La Scala is a farm to table restaurant. I went for lunch. I am not a real dressy person. I think dinner will be more dressy than casual. 

Rustic wood tables and upholstered chairs. 

Along with the pasta, sandwiches were on the menu. They looked good. 

I had the Ravioli Florentine in cream sauce sun-dried tomatoes and spinach. 

A small salad of field greens cucumber and carrots dressed in homemade balsamic vinaigrette came first.  Very tasty. 

With the ravioli a homemade personal loaf of herbed bread was served. Soft and fluffy with a crispy bottom. Mmm. 

Meal finished for under $17 with tip, no alcohol. 

I will return. 

The one problem is the parking. It is downtown Lafayette with street parking

We sat outside which was beautiful but the chairs were super uncomfy. The inside is dark and odd looking. It took a while for our food to come out which was disappointing. The seafood ravioli was good, but a bit strange and not a classic Italian taste. Good price. Amazing service!! Rebecca, our server was phenomenal!! Super kind, very professional. She accommodated my vegetarian needs and took her time with us.

My last experience was bad. I came here to order one more time staffed calamari. They were total different from the one month ago. Taste and look.In menu states that they suppose be staffed with crab meat and shrimp, I even didn't noticed any of those. The portion of this was also small. To pay over 20$ for rice-no thank you! I suggest the cook chief was different which make me disappointed. The waiter told me she will bring me more, never shown up with this. The service this visit was not the best either. Have feeling that  I'm not appreciated cus

Came here on a random week night with coworkers.  Heard good things about it from locals and thought we would try it out.  Ordered an appetizer that never arrived but luckily we also were not charged for it.  Entrees were mediocre but smothered in sauces and cheese.  Sauces were thick but not rich.    Flavor fell a little short too.  Dessert was the saving grace as the cannoli was legitimately good and quite authentic.  Wine selection was fine and they were kind enough to offer sampling's as well to my coworker who was undecided.  Menu is vast and offers something for all.  It seems to be a local staple restaurant and family owned.

I was in town for business and looked on Yelp for a dinner recommendation.  La Scala looked like my kind of place, so I headed there.  I sat at the bar and was greeted by James, who provided excellent t service.  They have a large menu, so it was tough to make a choice.  I wound up with the old standby, Veal Parmigiana.  I started with a house salad, which was very good with the balsamic vinaigrette dressing.  Their bread is also delicious with a good olive oil dipping sauce.  My veal was perfect...terrific tomato sauce with a perfect level of spice.  Good size portion and very reasonable prices.  Nice wine list as well.  La Scala is a great choice for Italian when in Lafayette!

This restaurant had the best energy and from the very beginning I knew that I'd love it. My server's name was pronounced 'Bow' not completely sure how he spells it. He answered all of my questions regarding the menu, he brought multiple samples of wine and even suggested his favs. Everything was to my liking and when the food finally came it was piping hot and delicious! The calamari was fresh and crispy. My white broccoli and cheddar soup was so good my friends sent their salads back and requested the soup togo. I'm definitely a "eat in bed" kind of girl so I took majority of my food togo so i coild eat it in bed . it was literally so good I couldn't enjoy it in a restaurant, it's definitely a comfort meal so i needed to be comfy. The Restaurant had low lights and soft music playing the vibe was LOVELY! Also there was lots of nice artwork hanging all throughout the restaurant. I'd definitely recommend. Ask for "Bow" or "Beau"
We love this place! Farm to table at its best. Plus the outdoor seating is . If you go - definitely get the bruschetta.

Who knew that most restaurants would be closed the week of July 4th? Luckily La Scala was open! We had a great dinner with homemade blue cheese dressing, homemade sauces and pasta. All of the entrees were great, and our server was lovely. Would definitely go back if I lived in Lafayette (we live in San Francisco).

Along with Red Seven and Bistro 501, this has to be one of the most well-to-do places in downtown Lafayette. I suggest getting your special event reservations for this place too a few months early.

Very classic Italian in both aesthetic, ambiance, and food. It's really cute inside, with the art, brick, and dark wood. Though the dining rooms are quite narrow, the high ceilings make up for it and the setting is actually quite intimate. Like Red Seven, the ambiance is quite flexible. You can go there casually with friends, but also on a date or professionally. It does feel a little more mature, classier, or kind of meant for older people, but you definitely get plenty of college students cycling through. On warmer nights, they also have the enclosed outdoor seating with fairy lights, and on warm nights it is its own kind of beautiful.

If you want something light, get something with the lemon sauce and pair it with their limoncello. However, my favorite is anything with the wine cream sauce. But ingredients are fresh, the pasta is handmade, and they really have something for everyone. Actually, honestly there isn't anything here I don't like. At the end of the meal, I like to have one of their desserts. Tiramisu (which is apparently imported) for dessert if you want to have something absolutely gorgeous at the end. The cannoli is good too, but you can get an equally delicious one at Vienna (coffee shop) for cheaper. They have different kinds of the fresh bread on different days, though I'm not sure of the scheduling a the moment.

The wait staff are WONDERFUL. In my rush, I once forgot my credit card at La Scala, and they held onto it for me until I got it back. Even better, they verified my identity before doing it, which I appreciate. Also, I had this one incident with some friends and their family where the numbers kept shifting (some people got stuck in traffic) and we sat down to eat and then they came, and then some didn't--the point is that the staff were SUPER accommodating. Not to mention they just rolled with whatever kind of diet the people I brought/with threw at them.

For a smaller taste, check them out at the downtown food festival Lafayette holds every summer. They almost always have a booth there. Best bet is to park in the garage behind Red Seven. From there, take the doors into the bank offices (I've never actually seen them lock), and walk out through the lobby. It'll place you smack dab on the street corner where you just cross the street and you're pretty much there.

So we walked by this place Saturday and it was quite busy in the courtyard and it smelled heavenly. We were with our freshman who would not have appreciated the deliciousness inside so we went elsewhere. We were going to be here for two more nights. Closed Sunday but went back Monday night. It was again quite busy. The very friendly host found us a table outside and since they were short on staff waited on us himself. 

The bread was a nice treat to start. I had the beef canneloni. I love that they use local ingredients including the beef. The tricolor pasta sheets were a thing to behold. I did not waste a bite of this dish. There is so much that I wanted to try on that menu I'm sure I'll get something different next time but maybe not. Loved sitting outside in the courtyard.

reviews.text: Located just down the hill from the Purdue campus, this is quite simply the place everyone goes before and after games. Locally owned, Bruno's is a beloved and iconic pizza place for those who live nearby as well as those who have driven many miles to return to campus. Everything on the menu is good and the service is excellent, even when the place is completely full. They make the pizzas behind a glass window right next to the front door as you enter. Parking can be an issue, but there is a constant turn over. Be patient for a few minutes and someone will be leaving shortly. You can call ahead to reserve a table and of course, there is carry out as well.

Bruno's is absolutely delicious! And I love their family atmosphere and how friendly the entire staff is. It's very much a family business and they care about their customers. I've gone here pre-COVID-19, but this review is in regards to their current take-out. The quality and service did not falter by any means. The pizza was ready and hot to take home and everything was nicely packed. There were many people on staff and everything seemed working like a machine, organized and quick. So many moving hands knowing what to do, working diligently and fast. They were very happy to see us and grateful for our loyalty. Their pizza was fresh, super filling, and extra cheese? Yeah, it really means extra cheese and we were very thankful for it!

I've been coming to Bruno's for the majority of my life as a Purdue fan and now as a student. It is the best pizza in West Lafayette, and I don't think it's a close competition. Bruno's is a true family business, and the standards have never once changed. While I have never tried any of their pasta dishes, I have no reason to believe they aren't fantastic. The pizzas are always great. Even with COVID-19 limiting the business to carry-out only, I have never had a bad pizza from Bruno's. The inside of the restaurant is a must-see for Purdue fans. Big O's collection of Purdue memorabilia is truly special. I look forward to the day when I can dine-in again!

Got a pizza to go... although I didn't get a chance to eat in, I did go in and check out the inside bit, and I have to say - this is a really cute restaurant! It was packed on a Friday night, and I loved the dim lighting and casual feel of the place. The gentleman who served us was very friendly and polite, despite the rush hour.

In terms of the pizza... I got the Bruno's veggie with jalapeños as extra topping (14 inch, came to approx $20). To be honest, I was quite disappointed. They definitely like their cheese, which I'm a big fan of, but it looked like the cheese had been poured over the toppings, so the toppings were quite soggy under all of that melted goo. The crust and base were not impressive and were a little harder than I'd like. 

I might go back to try a non-veg pizza, but if you're a vegetarian looking for a good veggie pizza, I can't recommend Bruno's.

Bruno's is a West Lafayette institution, famous for scissor-cut pizza, Big O's sports memorabilia, and fried dough balls covered in garlic butter and Parmesan. Generations of Boilermaker faithful love this place, and I suspect generations more will too, but not me. I've had enough. 

The pizza ingredients are good, but I prefer mine fully baked, thank you. There's not a square inch of browned cheese in sight at Bruno's. Melted, yes, for the most part. Browned? Ah, no. The restaurant has a very loud sports-themed dining room, covered in sports memorabilia. At full capacity, this room is a claustrophobic cacophony of screaming kids, ESPN, and birthday parties. The Swiss room plays homage to the original Bruno location across State Street, which had a Swiss chalet feel. Chalk that location up to progress and new roads. There's a bar room in the back. 

The best thing on the menu - an antipasto meat and cheese plate - is no more. The final straw was when we were refused a take out cup for WATER. Classic. We got the Heisman on grandma's request for a cup of water for the road. Two pizzas, two sodas, all for $45, mediocre service for free. Sorry Boiler Nation, I won't return to Bruno's. Overrated and overpriced.

Heart eyes all around!! My in-laws treated my husband and I to pizza and Bruno dough on our most recent excursion to Lafayette. I've heard about this place for so long and was not disappointed once I got tri it! From the crispy fried Bruno dough to their loaded pizzas, we left with full tummies and full hearts. 

Be sure to check out all their extensive Purdue memorabilia- it pays homage to all the best Boliermakers.

Drew Brees No Cheese! More meat than a cattle ranch. 

Our server was super friendly. The dough balls are a must too.

If you like Drew Brees like I do, there is a ginormous bobble head Brees to take a photo with. Lots of TVs for football. Enough Purdue memorabilia to be a museum. 

Must stop while in town.

Too bad Brunos felt the need to go to a new model of private events.  We used to hit Brunos every time we were in Lafayette.  Can't do that anymore.  They are open only to private parties.  I live too far away to do a takeout.  Maybe they'll have a change of heart and open up the dining rooms eventually.
Absolutely fantastic. Cannot come back to Lafayette without going to Bruno's. I was great to see Orlando, Bruno and they're fantastic staff.

GO NEXT DOOR TO PUCCINO'S YOU WONT BE DISAPPOINTED !!!!!

You won't get the history that Bruno's has but will get a much better Pizza

Worst experience I've had here and will not be coming back.

Got the crustless pizza and was cheese only, no more than 8oz of cheese and some  sauce, $14.95 which is more than a large cheese pizza with crust and twice as much cheese and sauce WOW!!!! 

I don't mind paying but Unbelievable that they feel comfortable charging this much for just cheese and sauce.
Get the Bruno dough, you will not regret it. Bruno's is excellent pizza, great service if you choose to dine-in, it's an excellent place to enjoy pizza and watch Purdue play.

Boiler Up! This place is fun and full of Purdue school spirit. We took the fam here for a Friday night trip to town and we loved it. My wife and I used to eat here when we were at Purdue and it just gets better with time. Must get Bruno Dough!! Pick a pizza any pizza and grab a beer. Enjoy!

This was a favorite restaurant of my husband during his time at Purdue several years ago. After a few visits on our own, and now with kiddos, it is one of my favorites as well! At first glance one could think their menu is what you'd expect to see at a standard pizza joint - but upon closer glance you'll find some really unique menu items: Apple butter & PB dipping sauce for the Bruno Dough on the kids menu, chicken livers on the spaghetti a la caruso, and even a cheese and peanut butter pizza!

My favorite bits about Bruno's:
-Memorabilia everywhere - all signed with the owner, Orlando's name! It is clear that he is well-loved. And, my toddler LOVES to explore the restaurant to check it all out. 
-The bruno dough - basically donuts made of pizza dough (8 per order). We get it with the meat sauce, which is also the same meat sauce used in the pasta dishes. It is outstanding.
-They're kid friendly - meaning they've got a kids menu with decent portions of real food, they serve milk, they provide crayons and paper, and they have slings and booster seats available.
-The house salad reminds me of the mixed vegetable salads from my time studying in Germany. It comes with radishes, egg, chopped beets, shredded carrots, and more. Yum. :)

My only beef with Bruno's is that the tap water tastes a little bit off. I don't know any other way to put it, but if you're between a water and a beer, get a beer. ;)
Service was nice. Pizza was undercooked but the more I saw other pizzas and photos, maybe that is how they cook their crust. Sauce lacked flavor. No decent wine options.

The pizza is nothing to go crazy about. It's cut really weird so it's hard to eat. The service wasn't bad. Although my side salad looked like it was from an 80's diner, was not good at all. It's just one of those famous purdue sports puds. The atmosphere was cool but other than that it was nothing to rave about.

The cliche family spot for the Purdue student for all the right reasons. Tasty variety of pizzas, nice assorted salads and pastas, and perhaps best of all for the family needs a welcoming and accommodating staff able and eager to handle large groups. For you bored types, the classic peanut butter pizza is a must try. I love about three pieces of it then never think of it again til next time here. Bruno's is the classic dinner joint for making memories and has dished out top service since my first pizza here back in their old building. Five stars for sure!

Another wonderful visit to Bruno's. This is the real deal when it comes to great pizza. We visited here tonight and had our regular order. We had a large pizza with mushroom and pepperoni, Bruno dough, side salads, coffee.  Just amazing tasting meal. This is a neighborhood gem.  Busy place with quality service. Friendly place that has many more menu choices. Brimming with Purdue memorabilia. Television tuned to sports games. Always a festive atmosphere. Bruno's always does it right. Can never wait to return again. Thanks management and staff.

Delicious pizza in a friendly place. I would suggest the bruno doigh as an appetizer. 

 Jeffver and he was friendly and very efficient. 

We'll be back!

After our service tonight, I don't care if I ever visit thus restaurant again.  The pizza we ordered was mixed up for another pizza at our table & when the waiter took our other pizza back because it was missing ONIONS, the kitchen staff (pizza maker) simply threw a hand full of RAW ONIONS on the pizza & then sent it back to our table.  What's wrong with this is so many things... 1) it took about 10 minutes & by the time the waiter returned, the pizza wasn't even close to being warm...let alone, hot. 2) as stated before, they simply threw a bunch of RAW ONIONS on it & sent it back out to us. 3) when I tried to explain to the waiter/kitchen pizza maker person, he was totally rude about it & 4) the dough wasn't cooked through.  

I have to say, that I realize in a college town, my lonely review is probably the least of their concern, but...they need to STOP & think that they need to try a little harder and mak e the dining experience for people who drove 45 minutes to get there a little better.
Good pizza, neat old sports decor. I've only had pizza. Try the apple butter pizza! Also, Bruno dough is a must try!!!
